subject: RE: [junit] [OT] coverage plugins for eclipse?
msgSnippet: This doesn t exactly answer your question, but we use EMMA on the projects I work on.  It s not integrated with Eclipse, but it works well and is free.  I
messageBody:
This doesn't exactly answer your question, but
we use EMMA on the projects I work on. It's not
integrated with Eclipse, but it works well and
is free. I haven't really found great need to
integrate my coverage tool with my IDE, because
of the way I use it. I'm usually interested in
running a whole bunch of tests and then seeing
how my coverage looks for the whole suite. Then,
I drill down, notice I missed some methods or
classes or whatever, and then go write tests for
those. Maybe I'm not using coverage analysis to
its full benefit, but I don't really do coverage
in small iterations (unlike TDD with JUnit).


Todd.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Thomas L Roche
> Sent: Thursday, September 01, 2005 6:28 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] [OT] coverage plugins for eclipse?
>
> Apologies if this is OT, but IMHO coverage measurement (for
> guiding one's test writing) and IDEs (for writing and running
> one's tests) are both at least tangentially related to JUnit
> ... and I don't know of a good list for coverage measurement :-(
>
> I'm wondering, what are folks who use Eclipse (or Eclipse-based
> products) using to do coverage measurement and reporting? One
> option is to just run the coverage tool from the command line
> or ant, but I'd really like something more integrated, e.g.
>
> 0 a run config that would Run>{JUnit, JUnit Plug-in Test} under the
> coverage tool and display results in a view
>
> 1 mark un/covered sources in Outline view or editors
>
> The coverage plugins of which I'm aware are
>
> * Clover
>
> * jcoverage
>
> * Rational Developer (Unfortunately its coverage tools are part of its
> performance-testing tools, which complicates installation and use
> for "normal" testing.)
>
> Are there others?
>
>
